Two-Component Mixture Model
Suppose we have a model as such:

Y1∼N(μ1,σ12)Y2∼N(μ2,σ22)Y=(1−Δ)Y1+ΔY2\begin{aligned} &Y_1\sim N(\mu_1, \sigma_1^2)\\ &Y_2\sim N(\mu_2, \sigma_2^2)\\ &Y= (1-\Delta)Y_1+\Delta Y_2 \end{aligned}​Y1​∼N(μ1​,σ12​)Y2​∼N(μ2​,σ22​)Y=(1−Δ)Y1​+ΔY2​​
where
Δ∈{0,1} with P(Δ=1)=π\Delta\in\{0,1\}\ with\ P(\Delta=1)=\pi Δ∈{0,1} with P(Δ=1)=π
Therefore, the density function of
YYY
is
f(y)=(1−π)ϕθ1(y)+πϕθ2(y)f(y)=(1-\pi)\phi_{\theta_1}(y)+\pi\phi_{\theta_2}(y)f(y)=(1−π)ϕθ1​​(y)+πϕθ2​​(y)
Then the log-likelihood would be
log⁡L(θ;Z)=∑i=1Nlog⁡[(1−π)ϕθ1(y)+πϕθ2(y)]\mathcal{\log{L}}(\theta;Z)=\sum_{i=1}^N\log{[(1-\pi)\phi_{\theta_1}(y)+\pi\phi_{\theta_2}(y)]}logL(θ;Z)=i=1∑N​log[(1−π)ϕθ1​​(y)+πϕθ2​​(y)]
It would be hard to calculate the MLE estimator. But if we have the
Δi\Delta_iΔi​
, then the log-likelihood would be

log⁡L(θ;Z,Δ)=∑i=1N[(1−Δi)log⁡ϕθ1(y)+Δilog⁡ϕθ2(y)]+∑i=1N[(1−Δi)log⁡(1−π)+Δilog⁡π]\begin{aligned} \mathcal{\log{L}}(\theta;Z,\Delta)=&\sum_{i=1}^N[(1-\Delta_i)\log{\phi_{\theta_1}(y)}+\Delta_i\log{\phi_{\theta_2}(y)}]\\ &+\sum_{i=1}^N[(1-\Delta_i)\log{(1-\pi)}+\Delta_i\log{\pi}] \end{aligned}logL(θ;Z,Δ)=​i=1∑N​[(1−Δi​)logϕθ1​​(y)+Δi​logϕθ2​​(y)]+i=1∑N​[(1−Δi​)log(1−π)+Δi​logπ]​
And the MLE will be much easier.
However, since
Δi\Delta_iΔi​
is unknown, we will proceed in an iterative fashion, substituting for each
Δi\Delta_iΔi​
in its expected value
γi(θ)=E(Δi∣θ,yi)=Pr(Δi=1∣θ,yi)\gamma_i(\theta)=E(\Delta_i|\theta,y_i)=Pr(\Delta_i=1|\theta,y_i)γi​(θ)=E(Δi​∣θ,yi​)=Pr(Δi​=1∣θ,yi​)
From Bayes rule

P(Δi=1∣yi,θ)=P(Δi=1,y∣θ)P(y∣θ)=P(y∣Δi=1,θ)P(Δi=1∣θ)P(y∣Δi=0,θ)P(Δi=0∣θ)+P(y∣Δi=1,θ)P(Δi=1∣θ)=ϕθ2(yi)πϕθ2(yi)π+ϕθ1(yi)(1−π)\begin{aligned} P(\Delta_i=1|y_i, \theta)&=\frac{P(\Delta_i=1,y|\theta)}{P(y|\theta)}\\ &=\frac{P(y|\Delta_i=1,\theta)P(\Delta_i=1|\theta)}{P(y|\Delta_i=0,\theta)P(\Delta_i=0|\theta)+P(y|\Delta_i=1,\theta)P(\Delta_i=1|\theta)}\\ &=\frac{\phi_{\theta_2}(y_i)\pi}{\phi_{\theta_2}(y_i)\pi+\phi_{\theta_1}(y_i)(1-\pi)} \end{aligned}P(Δi​=1∣yi​,θ)​=P(y∣θ)P(Δi​=1,y∣θ)​=P(y∣Δi​=0,θ)P(Δi​=0∣θ)+P(y∣Δi​=1,θ)P(Δi​=1∣θ)P(y∣Δi​=1,θ)P(Δi​=1∣θ)​=ϕθ2​​(yi​)π+ϕθ1​​(yi​)(1−π)ϕθ2​​(yi​)π​​
this is also called as the
responsibility
for observation
iii
. We use a procedure called the EM algorithm.
Take initial guesses for the parameters
μ^1,σ^12,μ^2,σ^22,pi^\hat{\mu}_1, \hat{\sigma}_1^2, \hat{\mu}_2, \hat{\sigma}_2^2, \hat{pi}μ^​1​,σ^12​,μ^​2​,σ^22​,pi^​
Expectation Step
: compute the responsibility
γ^i=ϕθ2(yi)πϕθ2(yi)π+ϕθ1(yi)(1−π)\hat{\gamma}_i=\frac{\phi_{\theta_2}(y_i)\pi}{\phi_{\theta_2}(y_i)\pi+\phi_{\theta_1}(y_i)(1-\pi)}γ^​i​=ϕθ2​​(yi​)π+ϕθ1​​(yi​)(1−π)ϕθ2​​(yi​)π​
Maximization Step
: compute the weighted means and variance. (notice the soft assignment.)

μ^1=∑i=1N(1−γ^i)yi∑i=1N(1−γ^i), σ^12=∑i=1N(1−γ^i)(yi−μ^1)2∑i=1N(1−γ^i)μ^2=∑i=1Nγ^iyi∑i=1Nγ^i, σ^12=∑i=1Nγ^i(yi−μ^1)2∑i=1Nγ^i\begin{aligned} \hat{\mu}_1=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^N(1-\hat{\gamma}_i)y_i}{\sum_{i=1}^N(1-\hat{\gamma}_i)}&,\ \hat{\sigma}_1^2=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^N(1-\hat{\gamma}_i)(y_i-\hat{\mu}_1)^2}{\sum_{i=1}^N(1-\hat{\gamma}_i)}\\ \hat{\mu}_2=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^N\hat{\gamma}_iy_i}{\sum_{i=1}^N\hat{\gamma}_i}&,\ \hat{\sigma}_1^2=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^N\hat{\gamma}_i(y_i-\hat{\mu}_1)^2}{\sum_{i=1}^N\hat{\gamma}_i}\\ \end{aligned}μ^​1​=∑i=1N​(1−γ^​i​)∑i=1N​(1−γ^​i​)yi​​μ^​2​=∑i=1N​γ^​i​∑i=1N​γ^​i​yi​​​, σ^12​=∑i=1N​(1−γ^​i​)∑i=1N​(1−γ^​i​)(yi​−μ^​1​)2​, σ^12​=∑i=1N​γ^​i​∑i=1N​γ^​i​(yi​−μ^​1​)2​​
Iterate 2 and 3 until convergence.
The EM Algorithm in General
EM algorithm is for problem like above that are  difficult to maximize the likelihood, but is easier to enlarge the sample with latent (unobserved) data. This is called
data augmentation
As for the general formulation of the EM algorithm. Assume the log-likelihood is
L(θ,Z)\mathcal{L}(\theta, Z)L(θ,Z)
and the latent variable
ZmZ^mZm
. Let
T=(Z,Zm)T=(Z, Z^m)T=(Z,Zm)
For the above problem,
(Z,Zm)=(y,Δ)(Z, Z^m)=(y, \Delta)(Z,Zm)=(y,Δ)
The EM algorithm would be:
Initialize
θ^(0)\hat{\theta}^{(0)}θ^(0)
Expectation Step
: at the
jjj
th step, compute:
Q(θ′,θ^(j))=E(L0(θ′;T)∣Z,θ^(j))Q(\theta',\hat{\theta}^{(j)})=E(\mathcal{L_0}(\theta'; T)|Z, \hat{\theta}^{(j)})Q(θ′,θ^(j))=E(L0​(θ′;T)∣Z,θ^(j))
as a function of the dummy argument
θ′\theta'θ′
Maximization Step
: determine the new estimate
θ^(j+1)\hat{\theta}^{(j+1)}θ^(j+1)
as the maximizer of
Q(θ′,θ^(j))Q(\theta', \hat{\theta}^{(j)})Q(θ′,θ^(j))
over
θ′\theta'θ′
.,  that is
θ^(j+1)=argmax⁡θ′Q(θ′,θ^(j))\hat{\theta}^{(j+1)}=arg\max_{\theta'}Q(\theta', \hat{\theta}^{(j)})θ^(j+1)=argθ′max​Q(θ′,θ^(j))
Iterate steps 2 and 3 until convergence.
There are two major problem for us now to solve. First is why this algorithm is correct and second, how is this algorithm with the weird
QQQ
the same as the algorithm we used in the previous section.
From the Bayes rule, we have
Pr(Zm∣Z,θ′)=Pr(Zm,Z∣θ′)Pr(Z∣θ′)Pr(Z^m|Z, \theta')=\frac{Pr(Z^m,Z| \theta')}{Pr(Z| \theta')}Pr(Zm∣Z,θ′)=Pr(Z∣θ′)Pr(Zm,Z∣θ′)​
So we have
Pr(Z∣θ′)=Pr(T∣θ′)Pr(Zm∣Z,θ′)Pr(Z|\theta')=\frac{Pr(T| \theta')}{Pr(Z^m|Z, \theta')}Pr(Z∣θ′)=Pr(Zm∣Z,θ′)Pr(T∣θ′)​
And correspond to log-likelihood:
log⁡L(θ′,Z)=log⁡L0(θ′,T)−log⁡L1(θ′,Zm∣Z)\mathcal{\log{L}}(\theta',Z)=\mathcal{\log{L}_0}(\theta',T)-\mathcal{\log{L}_1}(\theta',Z^m|Z)logL(θ′,Z)=logL0​(θ′,T)−logL1​(θ′,Zm∣Z)
And notice the two term at left are all function of
ZmZ^mZm
. If we take conditional expectation,

L(θ′,Z)=E[L0(θ′,T)∣Z,θ]−E[L1(θ′,Zm∣Z)∣Z,θ]=Q(θ′,θ)−R(θ′,θ)\begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}(\theta',Z)&=E[\mathcal{L_0}(\theta',T)|Z, \theta]-E[\mathcal{L_1}(\theta',Z^m|Z)|Z, \theta]\\ &=Q(\theta', \theta)-R(\theta', \theta) \end{aligned}L(θ′,Z)​=E[L0​(θ′,T)∣Z,θ]−E[L1​(θ′,Zm∣Z)∣Z,θ]=Q(θ′,θ)−R(θ′,θ)​
For the above problem,
log⁡L(θ′,Z)=∑i=1Nlog⁡[(1−π)ϕθ1(y)+πϕθ2(y)]\mathcal{\log{L}}(\theta',Z)=\sum_{i=1}^N\log{[(1-\pi)\phi_{\theta_1}(y)+\pi\phi_{\theta_2}(y)]}logL(θ′,Z)=i=1∑N​log[(1−π)ϕθ1​​(y)+πϕθ2​​(y)]
And

log⁡L0(θ′;Z,Δ)=∑i=1N[(1−Δi)log⁡ϕθ1(y)+Δilog⁡ϕθ2(y)]+∑i=1N[(1−Δi)log⁡(1−π)+Δilog⁡π]\begin{aligned} \mathcal{\log{L_0}}(\theta';Z,\Delta)=&\sum_{i=1}^N[(1-\Delta_i)\log{\phi_{\theta_1}(y)}+\Delta_i\log{\phi_{\theta_2}(y)}]\\ &+\sum_{i=1}^N[(1-\Delta_i)\log{(1-\pi)}+\Delta_i\log{\pi}] \end{aligned}logL0​(θ′;Z,Δ)=​i=1∑N​[(1−Δi​)logϕθ1​​(y)+Δi​logϕθ2​​(y)]+i=1∑N​[(1−Δi​)log(1−π)+Δi​logπ]​
And

Q(θ′,θ)=E[L0(θ′,T)∣Z,θ]=∑i=1N[(1−E[Δi∣Z,θ])log⁡ϕθ1(y)+E[Δi∣Z,θ]log⁡ϕθ2(y)]+∑i=1N[(1−E[Δi∣Z,θ])log⁡(1−π)+E[Δi∣Z,θ]log⁡π]=∑i=1N[(1−γ^i)log⁡ϕθ1(y)+γ^ilog⁡ϕθ2(y)]+∑i=1N[(1−γ^i)log⁡(1−π)+γ^ilog⁡π]\begin{aligned} Q(\theta', \theta)&=E[\mathcal{L_0}(\theta',T)|Z, \theta]\\ &=\sum_{i=1}^N[(1-E[\Delta_i|Z, \theta])\log{\phi_{\theta_1}(y)}+E[\Delta_i|Z, \theta]\log{\phi_{\theta_2}(y)}]\\ &+\sum_{i=1}^N[(1-E[\Delta_i|Z, \theta])\log{(1-\pi)}+E[\Delta_i|Z, \theta]\log{\pi}]\\ &=\sum_{i=1}^N[(1-\hat{\gamma}_i)\log{\phi_{\theta_1}(y)}+\hat{\gamma}_i\log{\phi_{\theta_2}(y)}]+\sum_{i=1}^N[(1-\hat{\gamma}_i)\log{(1-\pi)}+\hat{\gamma}_i\log{\pi}] \end{aligned}Q(θ′,θ)​=E[L0​(θ′,T)∣Z,θ]=i=1∑N​[(1−E[Δi​∣Z,θ])logϕθ1​​(y)+E[Δi​∣Z,θ]logϕθ2​​(y)]+i=1∑N​[(1−E[Δi​∣Z,θ])log(1−π)+E[Δi​∣Z,θ]logπ]=i=1∑N​[(1−γ^​i​)logϕθ1​​(y)+γ^​i​logϕθ2​​(y)]+i=1∑N​[(1−γ^​i​)log(1−π)+γ^​i​logπ]​
Therefore, the
θ\thetaθ
for the above problem is
γ^i\hat{\gamma}_iγ^​i​
θ\thetaθ
are parameter that is calculated by the parameter previous iteration (
θ^(i)\hat{\theta}^{(i)}θ^(i)
And the question now is why only maximizing
QQQ
could end up get the maximal value for
log⁡L\log{L}logL
